key_value_pairs.value: Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software
Charles Petzold
Microsoft Press
Corbis Images
Joel Panchot
Explains how computers work without using metaphors or similes.
Readers seeking a deep understanding of computer workings, potentially rivaling that of electrical engineers and programmers.
Hierarchical, moving from transistors to information displayed on screens.
Traces computer development back to 19th-century technology.
Uses antique technology (telegraph equipment) to illustrate computer construction.
Relaxed pace despite technical depth.
A binary code using dots and dashes (or short and long blinks) to represent letters, numbers, and punctuation.
A 6-bit binary code using raised dots in a 2x3 cell to represent characters.
Explores decimal, octal, quaternary, and binary number systems.
Explains Boolean algebra and its relationship to electrical circuits.
Describes AND, OR, NAND, NOR, XOR gates and their implementation using relays or transistors.
Details the construction of an 8-bit binary adder using logic gates.
Explains subtraction using nines' complement (decimal) and ones' complement (binary).
Describes two's complement representation of negative numbers.
Explores R-S and D-type flip-flops, including level-triggered and edge-triggered versions.
Details the construction of RAM arrays using flip-flops and selectors.
Defines these units of memory and their relationship to powers of 2.
Describes the automation of addition and subtraction using RAM and a counter.
Presents a computer design with a processor, memory, input/output devices, and control signals.
Introduces assembly language programming and its relationship to machine code.
Compares assembly language to high-level languages such as ALGOL, FORTRAN, COBOL, Pascal, C, and others.
Explains the American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) and its limitations.
Describes the Extended Binary Coded Decimal Interchange Code (EBCDIC).
Introduces Unicode as a universal character encoding system.
Explains the role of a computer bus in connecting components.
Details the design of a keyboard interface using a counter, decoder, and selector.
Describes floppy disks and hard disks and their interfaces.
Explores the functions of an operating system, using CP/M and MS-DOS as examples.
Discusses the development of GUIs, including the Xerox Alto and the Apple Macintosh.
Compares fixed-point and floating-point number representation in computers.
Explains the IEEE standard for single-precision and double-precision floating-point numbers.
Covers digital sound, music, and movies, including compression techniques.
Briefly describes the Internet, World Wide Web, and related technologies.

context: PDF Document: code-charles-petzold.pdf, Pages: 363, Title: Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software
